awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Hurricane Harvey: Experiences, Recovery and Future Policies
awd_abstract_narration:
This study investigates the behaviors and opinions of Hurricane Harvey survivors living in the Houston metropolitan region including Harris, Fort Bend, Brazoria, and Montgomery Counties. What actions did residents take in preparation of the storm? How were evacuations and rescues completed? Since Hurricane Sandy, social media has become an integral part of disaster response. How did residents use social media before and after Hurricane Harvey? The study will identify the characteristics and motivations of volunteers who participated in the evaluation, clean up and reconstruction efforts, and whether social media played a role in spurring individuals to act in support of their community. The broader impact of this panel survey centers on not only the new data that can contribute to basic research, but to the information it provides to policymakers as part of the policy evaluation and policymaking processes and the information it provides to private sector decision makers 

The intellectual merit of this panel survey, because it surveys the same units over time, increases direct scientific knowledge on the role of communication and response by individuals during emergency situations.   Another attribute of a panel study would be the contributions to basic science.  Specifically, this data can be used to test important behavioral theories on crisis response and attitudes toward government and help add to a literature in the political and social sciences that links existing and proposed policies to outcomes.  The initial survey of active cell and landline telephone users living in highly impacted areas in Harris, Fort Bend, Brazoria and Montgomery Counties. It is very important to secure resources to field the survey instrument as soon as possible. In addition to demographic characteristics such as race, education, income, gender and age, the survey questions will cover topics such as: i) sources of information about Hurricane Harvey; ii) damages due to Hurricane Harvey; iii) the use of social media for seeking and sharing information, identifying rescue needs, volunteerism, and donations; iv) evaluation of government responses; v) expected policy changes. The project will also take advantage of previous surveys conducted after Tropical Storm Allison, and Hurricanes Katrina, Rita and Ike.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
When Hurricane Harvey made landfall on Texas in August 2017, nearly 780,000 Texans were forced to leave their homes to evacuate to safety, over 120,000 people and over 5,000 pets had to be rescued from the flood waters, and 88 people lost their lives. Houston and surrounding areas suffered damages as Harvey dropped over 48 inches of water in some areas. The Greater Houston area experienced the largest rainfall that has ever been recorded in the United States from a single storm. At least 18 inches of water inundated nearly 80,000 homes in Texas because of Harvey, with about 23,000 of those homes having more than five feet of water inside.

In the immediate aftermath of the natural disaster, researchers at the University of Houston's Hobby School of Public Affairs launched a five-year survey-based study aimed at understanding the experience, recovery, and resiliency of Houstonians before, during, and after Hurricane Harvey. More specifically, we sought to address three goals. First, to identify which groups were affected the most by Hurricane Harvey. Second, to collect information about people's recovery and resiliency from that experience. Third, to address what policies and government responses had the best impact on the population.

After analyzing Hurricane Harvey's effects on Houstonians over the past five years, we found that Hurricane Harvey affected directly or indirectly over half of the respondents living in the Greater Houston area. The most affected areas were clustered near the Texas Gulf Coast region. Within Houston, where for most ZIP codes, over half of respondents were affected. Five years later, individuals in the Greater Houston area are still trying to recover from the damages wrought by Hurricane Harvey. Furthermore, using a measure of vulnerability derived from the Center for Disease Control's 2018 Social Vulnerability Index (SVI), we find that this is especially true for those vulnerable respondents. Ethno-racial minorities, specifically Hispanics, were the most affected, regardless of their income.

Our research also sought to understand patterns of cooperation during natural disasters. We find evidence consistent with earlier work documenting the negative impact of ethno-racial fragmentation on cooperation and spontaneous collective action in times of crises. We also find that institutionalized responses to natural disasters are weak, segregated groups within heterogeneous communities can overcome collective action problems and can rely on neighbors and kin to coordinate their responses in times of hardship.

Policies aimed at lessening these effects on a city- or state-wide level are an essential step to preparing for future weather-related events. Indeed, our studies over the past five years have repeatedly shown that most respondents support various policies aimed at mitigating flooding. The most supported policies were the construction of a new reservoir to protect West Houston, adopting new building codes that require homes built in flood-prone areas be elevated/raised to avoid flooding, passing greater restrictions on construction in flood plains, and preventing development and construction on native prairies and wetlands in western and northwestern portions of Harris County. All of these policies received 90% support across time. 

The results of our research are summarized in five reports available at https://uh.edu/hobby/harvey/ and numerous conference presentations of the discipline (American Political Science Association, Midwest Political Science Association, Southern Political Science Association), testimony, and public presentations, such as "Getting It Right: An All-Inclusive Emergency Planning Workshop Series?" a Houston Urban Area Security Initiative hosted by the Harris County Office of Homeland Security and Emergency Management. Our findings also appeared in the media, including ABC13, the Houston Chronicle, and Houston Public Media, among others.

The research has also trained four of our postdoctoral fellows, including one, Dr. Ching-Hsing Wang, who is currently an Assistant Professor at the National Cheng Kung University in Taiwan. Finally, our research has helped to inform public debates and policymaking on policies and initiatives aimed at preparation and response to future severe weather events that threaten the lives, property, and economic well-being of communities that have been affected or are likely to be affected by these events.
